name: Ankylosaurus
overview: Ankylosaurus is a dinosaur currently documented from Late Cretaceous (68-66 million years ago) in Western North America. Current interpretation suggests a herbivore feeding profile. It is typically classified as Ankylosaurid ornithischian. Evidence quality for Ankylosaurus is currently limited by specimen completeness and historical naming complexity. Dino-pedia tracks this taxon with conservative wording so future specimen-level studies can be integrated without overwriting uncertain claims.

externalAppearance.lips: Beaked snout likely sheathed in keratin

physiology.heartRate: Likely low resting rate for large armored herbivore
physiology.heartMass: Robust cardiovascular support for dense body

growthStages.oldAge: Armor wear and arthritic limbs likely

reproduction.eggs: Likely buried eggs similar to other ornithischians

biomechanics.pubicBoot: Broad pelvis for low-slung body support
biomechanics.footStructure: Wide stance and strong hindlimbs for club swings

pathologies.injuries: Armor and tail injuries likely from intraspecific impacts

stats.maxTooth: Relatively small compared to body size
stats.eyeSize: Small lateral eyes protected by armor
stats.tailWeight: Massive ossified club at tail end

funFacts: Its tail club was one of the most specialized weapons among dinosaurs
Body armor included fused bony plates

behaviorAndConflict.injuryEvidence: Skeletal trauma patterns are consistent with repeated defensive impacts.
behaviorAndConflict.socialBehavior: Probably mostly solitary or in loose small groups.
behaviorAndConflict.defensiveCombat: Tail club provided a powerful deterrent against large predators.
behaviorAndConflict.mainRivals: Large theropods, especially tyrannosaurids in shared habitats.

feedingPatterns.preferredPlants: Ferns, low shrubs, and tough understory plant material.
feedingPatterns.dailyIntake: Likely fed steadily on low vegetation throughout the day.
feedingPatterns.feedingStyle: Ground-level browsing using beak cropping and simple tooth processing.
feedingPatterns.digestiveStrategy: Bulk fermentation in a large gut compensated for simple teeth.

breedingAndNesting.parentalCare: Direct evidence is sparse; short-term nest attendance is possible.
breedingAndNesting.nestingCycle: Likely seasonal nesting in protected lowland sites.
breedingAndNesting.hatchlingSurvival: Juveniles were less armored and more vulnerable than adults.
breedingAndNesting.courtship: Display behavior may have included posture and tail movement signaling.

extinctionContext.immediateEffects: Rapid ecosystem instability reduced survivable herbivore niches.
extinctionContext.timeline: Lost at the end-Cretaceous mass extinction event.
extinctionContext.legacy: Central to studies of defensive evolution in large herbivores.
extinctionContext.primaryDrivers: K-Pg climate shock and food-web collapse.

fossilDiscoveryHistory.majorDiscoveries: Skull and armor finds clarified body protection strategies.
fossilDiscoveryHistory.museumImpact: An iconic armored dinosaur in public and educational exhibits.
fossilDiscoveryHistory.researchMilestones: Tail-club biomechanics work quantified impact potential.
fossilDiscoveryHistory.firstFinds: First described in the early 20th century from North American material.

locomotionAndAthletics.gait: Low, stable quadrupedal gait optimized for armored body support.
locomotionAndAthletics.endurance: Could likely sustain steady slow movement while browsing.
locomotionAndAthletics.maneuverability: Tail-club swing mechanics were more important than pursuit mobility.
locomotionAndAthletics.acceleration: Limited acceleration but strong short-range defensive bracing.

paleoecology.ecosystemRole: Armored megaherbivore resistant to many predatory attacks.
paleoecology.coexistingFauna: Shared ecosystems with hadrosaurs, ceratopsians, and large tyrannosaurids.
paleoecology.nicheShifts: Juveniles likely occupied safer niches before full armor development.
paleoecology.resourceDynamics: Likely tracked low vegetation near open woodland and floodplain edges.

sensoryAndIntelligence.cognition: Behavior likely prioritized threat detection and defensive positioning.
sensoryAndIntelligence.smell: Likely important for locating forage and detecting predators.
sensoryAndIntelligence.hearing: Probably tuned to ground-level environmental cues and low-frequency signals.
sensoryAndIntelligence.vision: Protected lateral eyes favored situational awareness over depth-focused predation vision.

researchContext.evidenceBase: Ankylosaurus is represented by published fossil material, but completeness and diagnostic overlap can limit high-confidence biological reconstruction.
researchContext.currentLimits: Several ecological and life-history traits remain inferential rather than directly measured for this taxon.
researchContext.nextDataNeeded: Priority evidence includes better-preserved cranial/postcranial overlap, robust stratigraphic control, and specimen-linked morphometrics.
researchContext.revisionOutlook: Interpretation is expected to improve as new finds and reanalyses clarify taxonomy and anatomy.
